tips.title: Verify Your Downloads
tips.content: Always verify the integrity of downloaded ISO files using checksums (MD5, SHA256) before installation to ensure they haven't been tampered with.

tips.title: Use Timeshift for Backups
tips.content: Timeshift is a powerful backup tool available on many Linux distributions. Create system snapshots before major updates or changes.

tips.title: Try Before You Install
tips.content: Most Linux distributions offer a 'live' mode that lets you try the OS without installing. Boot from USB and test compatibility with your hardware.

tips.title: Keep Your System Updated
tips.content: Regular updates improve security and stability. Use your distribution's package manager to keep your system up to date.

tips.title: Learn Basic Terminal Commands
tips.content: Familiarize yourself with basic commands like ls, cd, mkdir, and apt/dnf/pacman. The terminal is powerful and often faster than GUI tools.

tips.title: Check Hardware Compatibility
tips.content: Before choosing a distribution, check hardware compatibility, especially for Wi-Fi cards, graphics cards, and peripherals.

tips.title: Use Local Mirrors
tips.content: Configure your package manager to use mirrors geographically close to you for faster downloads and updates.

tips.title: Customize Your Desktop
tips.content: Linux offers extensive customization options. Explore different desktop environments (GNOME, KDE, XFCE) to find what works best for you.
